Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 10:17AM mb2226 wrote: Hi Melinda - I had a grade 3 1.2 CM (not mm) IDC and had a lumpectomy and radiation, followed by femara.  I was 49 when diagnosed.  2.6 mm is really, really tiny and grade 3 doesn't necessarily mean "aggressive" in the sense that it definitely spreads.  And yes, bc is pretty slow moving so don't worry about these few weeks. I would doubt seriously that you will need a mastectomy. Nobody ever even suggested I needed that, and my tumor was 6 times larger than yours. And, in bc - size matters a LOT.  So although I know its easier said than done -- you've got this really early, and the grade probably won't make any difference at all... best, mb

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 07:30AM mb2226 wrote: I had cording after the SNB procedure that was very painful and limited my mobility a LOT.  A friend of mine who is a physical therapist knew of another physical therapist who had had breast cancer and set me up with her.  She worked on the cording and after 3 sessions, my arm was perfect.  She broke up the scar tissue, which was painful, but the results were simply amazing. My surgeon and onc just told me to do the exercises but without the intervention of the PT I don't think it would have worked.  I had my SNB Oct. 27 and started physical therapy a month later -- the PT said the earlier you addressed it, the better.  Good luck, embee

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2008 07:54AM mb2226 wrote: I had cording, too, about the same time as you did. I went to a physical therapist (who had had breast cancer herself) and in 2 sessions she broke up the scar tissue and my arm was perfect. Never had another problem. My surgeon did not suggest this move -- they tend to give you exercises to do.  But I think having the PT do it makes things a lot faster and more effective.  I think it should be the standard of treatment for cording.  Good luck, MB
